They were just two people, standing by a giant pumpkin, with an entire, unspoken history crackling in the air between them. "Good turnout," she said finally, the words feeling flimsy and inadequate. He nodded, taking a sip of his coffee. "They greased the axle on the Ferris wheel this year. It's running about five percent faster."

It was such a quintessentially Harold observation that Susan felt a genuine, unforced smile touch her lips. "I wouldn't have noticed." she said. "I was just thinking the kid running the pumpkin booth looks terrified he's going to have to actually move it." Harold’s gaze shifted from the pumpkin to the gangly teenager with a clipboard, and a flicker of amusement registered in his eyes. He had been analyzing the object; she had been reading the person. It was a subtle shift in their dynamic, a balancing of perspectives. "You're probably right," he conceded. They stood for another moment, and then, as if by some unspoken agreement, they began to walk, drifting aimlessly along the packed dirt path between the booths. The movement was easier than the stillness, the shared motion a kind of conversation in itself. They didn't speak of the past, of porch lights or frayed cords or boxes full of sorrow. They spoke of the present. He told her about a persistent raccoon that had learned how to open the "animal-proof" latch on his workshop trash can. She told him about the surprising popularity of Scandinavian noir novels among Norman's elderly women.

The sun began to dip below the tree line, painting the sky in the same shades of dusty rose and grey that used to fill her bedroom at dawn. They found themselves near the parking lot, the festival winding down behind them. The easy rhythm of their walk slowed to a stop. "Well," he said, gesturing vaguely with his empty coffee cup. "I should..." She nodded, a familiar knot of social anxiety tightening in her chest. But this time was different. "Thank you for the coffee," she said, though they hadn't had any together. It was a clumsy acknowledgment of the shared time, the quiet companionship. "There wasn't any coffee," he said, a ghost of a smile playing on his lips. "But you're welcome." He looked at her then, his gaze direct, and added, "It was good to see you, Susan." The simple, unadorned statement held more warmth than a thousand polite platitudes. "You too, Harold," she replied, and the words were true. She watched him walk toward his plain white van, his solid, purposeful stride a familiar sight. She got into her own car and sat for a moment as the last of the light faded. The silence in the car was not the hollow ache of loneliness. It was a peaceful quiet, the feeling of a new, fragile connection having been tested, and holding firm. The goblin was gone, the ghost was at rest, and in their place, something new and quiet and cautiously hopeful was beginning to grow.

The first snow of winter fell not with the drama of a blizzard, but as a slow, deliberate act of erasure. Fat, wet flakes drifted down from a sky the colour of lead, muffling sound, blurring the town’s hard edges, and laying a uniform blanket of white over everything. It covered the last of the dead leaves, the manicured lawns, and the bright, persistent gold of Susan Blackwood’s marigolds, tucking the town in for a long, quiet sleep. Inside the Norman Public Library, the silence was of a different quality. It was a warm, living silence, punctuated by the soft rustle of turning pages and the quiet hum of the building’s old radiators. Susan sat at the main circulation desk, a stack of books to be processed on her left, a mug of steaming tea on her right. She was running a thin line of archival glue along the spine of a well-loved copy of *Charlotte’s Web*, her movements patient and precise. The work was a kind of meditation, a quiet act of preservation that soothed a part of her she hadn’t known was still restless.

Her world had reordered itself around these small, tangible acts. She had re-established contact with her sister in Oregon, their first phone call a stilted, awkward dance around years of unspoken pain, their more recent ones filled with the easy, mundane chatter of everyday life. She had even attended a meeting of the library's evening book club, a terrifying prospect that had turned out to be a surprisingly pleasant hour spent debating the merits of a historical novel with a group of women who knew her only as "Susan from the library." She was no longer a ghost or a goblin; she was a woman who fixed books, who had opinions on unreliable narrators, who was known to make a surprisingly good lemon drizzle cake, a recipe her sister had given her. The quiet cottage, once a tomb, was now simply her home, a place of warmth and books and the lingering scent of citrus and beeswax.

Harold Belchamber, meanwhile, was at Agnes Gable’s house, replacing the thermostat on her furnace. It was an annual pre-winter check-up he did for many of his elderly clients, a service he often under-billed, filing it under the mental category of preventative maintenance for the town’s fragile ecosystem. Agnes sat in her armchair, a plaid blanket over her knees, watching him with bright, curious eyes. The infamous violet pedicure was a distant, almost fond, memory now, a bizarre punctuation mark in the long, rambling sentence of her life. They no longer spoke of it, but an unspoken understanding lingered between them, a shared knowledge that some things were broken in ways that had nothing to do with wires. "It's supposed to be a bad one tonight, Harold," she said, her voice thin but clear. "The weatherman is all in a tizzy. Heavy, wet snow." Harold grunted in acknowledgment as he tightened a final screw on the new thermostat's housing. "That's what they're saying. This wet snow is the worst for the power lines. Heavy. Brings the branches down." He stood, wiping his hands on a rag from his back pocket. "But your heat is solid. You'll be fine." He packed his tools, the familiar metallic clicks a sound of reassurance in the quiet house. As he left, he made a mental note of the other homes on his informal watch list: Old Man Hemlock, Widow Jensen, and the small, cared-for cottage on the edge of town, now a beacon of steady light rather than a flickering anomaly.

The snow began to fall in earnest just after dusk. The fat, gentle flakes became a thick, driving curtain of white, whipped into a frenzy by a rising wind. The first flicker of the lights came around eight p.m., a brief, sickening dip that made the whole town collectively hold its breath. Ten minutes later, the world outside the windows went from a flickering tableau of white and black to absolute, impenetrable darkness. An overloaded transformer on the north side of town gave up with a percussive whump that was swallowed by the storm, and Norman was plunged into a sudden, primitive silence. Harold was in his workshop, reviewing invoices, when the power died. He didn't even flinch. He lit a Coleman lantern with a practiced hand, its steady hiss filling the sudden quiet. His phone, which had been silent, immediately began to ring. The next few hours were a triage of panicked calls. A farmer whose electric water pump for his livestock had failed. A young couple with a newborn, terrified of the cold. The manager of the Restful Fields cemetery, worried about the security system. Harold listened patiently to each one, giving calm, practical advice: check your breakers, don't open the freezer, use blankets to block the drafts under doors. He was a dispatcher of reassurance, promising to address the true emergencies as soon as the town's ploughs made the roads passable.

In her cottage, Susan was reading by the light of a single, fat beeswax candle, a thick quilt wrapped around her shoulders. When the lights went out, she felt a brief, primal jolt of fear, a phantom echo of a time when darkness had been her accomplice and her enemy. But it passed in a heartbeat, replaced by a calm, practical assessment of the situation. She lit two more candles, their warm glow pushing back the shadows. She filled the bathtub with water, just in case the pipes froze. She checked the batteries in her flashlight and radio. These were the simple, logical steps of a person who knew how to take care of herself, lessons learned not just from Harold, but from the slow, steady work of rebuilding her own life. She found herself thinking of Harold, picturing his phone ringing off the hook, imagining him out in the storm, a solitary figure working to restore the very system the town took for granted. She put her kettle on the small camp stove she had bought for just such an occasion, her worry for him a new and unfamiliar warmth inside her.

An hour later, a set of headlights cut a slow, cautious path through the blizzard outside her house. It was the unmistakable shape of a plain white work van. A deep thud came from her front door, the sound of a heavy fist knocking against the wood. Her heart didn't panic; it gave a strange, complicated leap. She opened the door to find Harold standing on her porch, covered in a thick layer of snow, his face red from the cold. He looked exhausted, solid, and immensely real. "Power's out," he stated, the words almost unnecessary. "Just checking my list. Making sure your pipes haven't burst." He wasn't there to rescue her. He was there as part of a methodical, responsible sweep, a man checking his circuits. "I'm fine, Harold," she said, stepping back from the door. The warm, candlelit air of her cottage spilled out onto the porch. "But you look frozen. Come in. I just made tea." He hesitated for only a second, then nodded, stomping the snow from his boots before crossing the threshold, bringing the clean, cold scent of the storm in with him. In the flickering candlelight, they were just two people, a man who fixed things and a woman who was learning to, sharing a small circle of light in the midst of the vast, silent dark.

He brought the biting cold in with him, a ghost of the storm that clung to his heavy coat and melted in small, dark pools on the entryway floor. Susan took the coat from him without a word, her movements sure and practiced, and hung it on a hook by the door, a simple act of hospitality that felt momentous. The last time he had been in this house at night, he had been an intruder, a diagnostician of sorrow. Now he was a guest, seeking refuge, and she was the one offering sanctuary. The cottage, lit by the warm, unsteady glow of half a dozen candles, felt like a ship's cabin, a small, self-contained world holding its own against the roaring chaos outside. The air smelled of beeswax, brewing tea, and the faint, clean scent of the pine logs stacked by her hearth, a fireplace she now knew how to use.

They sat at the small kitchen table where he had once sorted through the wreckage of her abandoned life. Now, its clean-scrubbed surface held only two steaming mugs, a plate of shortbread cookies, and a single candle whose flame danced and swayed, casting their faces in shifting relief. Outside, the wind howled, a physical, pressing force against the small house, but inside, a profound quiet held sway. They drank their tea, the silence comfortable, punctuated only by the storm and the soft clink of ceramic on wood. It was Harold who spoke first, his voice a low rumble that seemed to absorb the room’s excess silence. "The main branch over the Sycamore Street substation came down. Took the whole grid with it. It’ll be morning at least before they can even get a crew in to assess." He was giving a report, his default mode of communication, but it was also a way of sharing the burden of his knowledge, of explaining the magnitude of the night's work.

"Did you get to everyone?" Susan asked, her voice soft. She was picturing his list, the mental map of the town’s most fragile connections. "Mrs. Jensen’s generator kicked on fine. She was more worried about her prize-winning rose bushes than the cold. And Old Man Hemlock slept through the whole thing. The outage just made it quieter for him." He took another sip of tea, the warmth of the mug seeming to thaw something in his face. "This is my last stop on this side of town." His gaze drifted around the room, taking in the neatly stacked books on a new shelf, the small pot of herbs on the windowsill, the clean, uncluttered space. It was a different house. It had a different energy. The current was flowing properly now.

A particularly violent gust of wind rattled the kitchen window in its frame, a sudden, percussive sound that made them both look. "Sounds like it’s getting worse," Susan said, her voice steady. The sound no longer felt like a threat, merely a fact of the night. She looked back at Harold, at the deep lines of exhaustion etched around his eyes, the weariness in the set of his shoulders. For all his quiet strength, the storm was taking its toll. "You can’t go back out in this, Harold. It’s not safe, not even for you." The words came out before she had fully considered them, a simple statement of concern. She was not telling him what to do, but was stating an observable fact. He looked at her, then at the window where the snow was now a horizontal white blur, and gave a slow, tired nod of concession. He knew she was right. For a man whose life was built on mitigating risk, driving into the teeth of a blizzard for a non-emergency was illogical.

He stayed. There was no awkwardness in the decision, no negotiation. It was a simple, practical necessity dictated by the storm. He took the lumpy but comfortable armchair in the small living room, and she took the sofa, a thick quilt pulled over her legs. The candles cast long, dancing shadows on the walls, turning the familiar room into a place of quiet mystery. They didn't talk much more. There was no need. The shared silence was a conversation in itself, an acknowledgment of the long, strange path that had brought them to this moment, sitting together in a small, warm house while the world outside was consumed by a storm. He eventually drifted off to sleep in the chair, his head lolled to one side, the lines of exhaustion on his face finally smoothing out. Susan watched him for a moment, the steady rise and fall of his chest a comforting rhythm in the quiet room. She looked around at her home, at the steady light of the candles, and felt a sense of profound and quiet peace. She had invited the man who had seen her at her most broken into her sanctuary, and in doing so, had discovered it was strong enough to shelter them both.

The first thing Susan noticed was the quality of the silence. The howling of the storm had been replaced by a deep, profound hush that felt as if it had physical weight, pressing in on the small cottage. The world beyond the windows was a landscape of impossible, searing white, every familiar shape softened and made strange by the heavy blanket of snow. The light that filtered into the room was pale, clear, and unforgivingly bright. It was morning. She had slept deeply on the sofa, a dreamless, exhausted sleep, and now, in the cold, still air of the new day, she felt a quiet sense of renewal, as if the storm had scoured the world clean. Her gaze went first to the armchair. Harold was still there, asleep, the quilt she had draped over him during the night now pooled around his waist. In the unfiltered morning light, the lines of exhaustion on his face were starkly visible, but his expression in sleep was one of deep, untroubled rest. The sight of him, a solid, grounding presence in her living room, filled her not with anxiety or a sense of intrusion, but with a feeling of profound and simple rightness.

She moved with a practiced quiet, her stockinged feet making no sound on the wooden floor. She revived the dying embers in the hearth, adding a few small logs until a tentative flame flickered to life, its warmth a welcome counterpoint to the room's deep chill. She set the kettle to boil on the camp stove, the familiar hiss a small, domestic sound in the vast stillness. The smell of coffee brewing moments later was rich and dark, a promise of warmth and wakefulness. It was the scent that finally stirred him. Harold woke not with a start, but with a slow, deep intake of breath, his eyes opening and blinking against the brightness of the room. He looked disoriented for a fraction of a second, his gaze taking in the unfamiliar ceiling, the dancing flames in the hearth, and finally, Susan, standing by the stove with two mugs in her hands. A flicker of memory, of the storm and the exhaustion, crossed his face, and he straightened in the chair, running a hand over his unshaven jaw. "Morning," he said, his voice thick with sleep. "Morning," she replied, her own voice steady. "The storm passed. Coffee's ready."

They drank it at the kitchen table, the way they had the night before, but the dynamic had shifted. The candlelight intimacy had been replaced by the stark clarity of daylight. They were no longer two people seeking refuge, but a man who had a town to repair and a woman whose home he had shared. The practicality of the situation reasserted itself, a comfortable and familiar language for them both. He looked at his watch, a heavy, no-nonsense piece of equipment, and a frown creased his brow. "I need to go," he said, his voice now fully awake, tinged with the urgency of his profession. "The crews will be waiting. Half the town is probably trying to make toast on their gas grills by now." He stood, the sense of purpose radiating from him, the quiet man of the armchair once again replaced by Belchamber Electrical. He went to the door and shrugged on his coat, which was still damp but no longer soaking. Susan simply stood by the table, watching him. "Thank you," he said, turning to face her, his expression serious. "For the shelter. And the coffee."

"You would have frozen," she said, stating it as a simple fact, not an act of charity for which she required thanks. He paused, his hand on the doorknob, his gaze sweeping over the room one last time before landing on the fireplace. "That chimney flue will need cleaning before you use it too much more next winter," he said, his concern manifesting in his usual way, as a safety warning. "Creosote buildup. It’s a fire hazard." She felt a small smile touch her lips, a genuine, unforced expression of warmth. It was his way of caring, his vocabulary of repair. "I'll put it on the list," she promised. He gave a single, decisive nod, then opened the door. The sheer, blinding whiteness of the outside world flooded the small entryway. "Be careful, Harold," she said, the words slipping out, a simple, direct expression of her own concern. He looked back at her from the doorway, a flicker of something unreadable in his calm eyes, and for a moment, the quiet electrician and the grieving goblin who had met on a dark porch stood in a new and altered space. Then he just nodded again, turned, and walked out into the bright, broken world, leaving her alone in the warmth of her quiet, steady house.

The silence that descended after the van drove away was different. It was not the hollow ache of loneliness, but the peaceful solitude of a Sunday morning. The power was still out, a fact that Susan registered not as a crisis, but as a simple condition of the day, like the snow or the cold. It was an opportunity for quiet, for manual tasks, for a slower rhythm. She spent the morning reading by the window, the brilliant light reflecting off the snow making the pages almost glow. In the afternoon, feeling a new kind of creative energy, she decided to bake. Using the small, surprisingly effective camp oven she owned, and working by the steady light from the window, she mixed a simple dough for bread. The physical work of it, the kneading and the shaping, was deeply satisfying, a tangible act of creation. She was punching down the risen dough, her hands white with flour, when the lights flickered once, twice, and then came on with a steady, unwavering brightness. The refrigerator hummed to life, its familiar drone a reassuring return to normalcy. The whole town was reconnected, the break repaired. Susan looked around her newly illuminated kitchen, a small smile on her face. The return of power felt like an external confirmation of an internal state. The lights were on, and she was home.

The next day, she baked two loaves of the bread. They came out of the oven golden brown, their crusts crisp, filling the small cottage with a scent that was the absolute antithesis of acetone and sorrow. It was the smell of nourishment, of home, of life. She wrapped one of the loaves, still warm, in a clean, checkered tea towel. For a moment, she hesitated, a phantom echo of her old fear, the instinct to remain hidden, making her pause. But it was a weak, fading signal. She took her car keys, placed the wrapped loaf on the passenger seat, and drove through the slushy, half-ploughed streets to the address she had looked up in the phone book months ago, the one that corresponded with Belchamber Electrical. It was a small, neat brick house, indistinguishable from its neighbors, with a detached two-car garage at the end of the driveway that served as his workshop. The path to the workshop door had been meticulously cleared of snow and salted. Susan took a deep breath, walked up the path, and placed the warm loaf on the step in front of the door. Tucked into the folds of the tea towel was a small, plain card. On it, she had written only five words. *Thank you for the light.* She did not knock. She did not wait. She simply turned and walked back to her car, her steps sure and light. She was not a thief in the dark, leaving a bizarre calling card of her own pain. She was a woman in the bright light of day, leaving a simple gift of gratitude, a baker who had finally, fully, come home.

Harold found the loaf on the step of his workshop late the next afternoon. He had spent the day untangling the storm's aftermath, replacing fried circuit breakers and reconnecting downed service lines, and he was tired down to the marrow of his bones. He stopped, his hand on the workshop door, and stared. It was an anomaly in his world of predictable patterns. A loaf of bread, wrapped in a checkered tea towel, its warmth still palpable even through the thick fabric, radiating a gentle heat against the cold concrete. It was a well-made thing, he could tell even before he touched it. The shape was uniform, the crust a deep, perfect gold. He bent down, his knees cracking in protest, and picked it up. The weight was substantial, honest. Tucked into the cloth was a plain white card. He pulled it free and read the five simple words written in a steady, graceful hand. *Thank you for the light.*

He took the loaf inside. The air in his workshop, usually a sterile mix of ozone, metal, and solvent, was instantly transformed by the rich, yeasty scent of fresh bread. He placed the loaf on his clean workbench, next to a disassembled electric motor he had been meaning to rewind. For a long moment, he just stood there, looking at it. The bread was a tangible object, a unit of sustenance, a product of labour and chemistry. But the note made it something else entirely. It was a receipt for a service rendered, a final sign-off on the most complex and delicate repair of his career. It was confirmation that the circuit was not just closed, but stable, and that the current flowing through it was steady and warm. He didn't smile. It was not in his nature. But a deep, quiet sense of satisfaction, a feeling as solid and real as the workbench beneath his hands, settled over him. He went to the small kitchenette in the corner, found his sharpest knife, and cut a thick slice from the end of the loaf. He ate it standing right there, the motor’s copper windings glinting in the stark light of the single overhead bulb. The bread was good. It was real.

Winter thawed into a muddy spring, which in turn gave way to the deep, settled green of another summer. A new, unspoken routine established itself between the small cottage on the edge of town and the neat brick house with the workshop in the back. It was a language of practical, quiet gestures. One morning, Susan found a brand-new, professional-grade garden hose coiled neatly by her back steps, a silent replacement for the leaky, sun-cracked one she had been struggling with. A week later, Harold discovered a Mason jar of bright, sharp-tasting strawberry jam on his workshop doorstep, with a note that simply said, *From the farmers' market.* He helped her install a new ceiling fan before the worst of the summer heat set in; she left a container of cold-brewed iced tea for him on the porch while he worked. They were two solitary people who had, through a shared and secret history, learned to orbit each other at a respectful distance, their connection maintained by a steady, reliable current of mutual care rather than the erratic surges of romance or passion. It was a friendship built on the shared understanding of how easily things can break, and the quiet satisfaction of putting them back together.

They ran into each other on a Saturday morning at Henderson’s Hardware. The place was bustling, a weekend hive of homeowners with ambitious projects and urgent problems. Harold was examining the structural integrity of a new line of German-made shovels. Susan was in the next aisle, staring at a wall of paint swatches, a furrow of indecision on her brow. "The semi-gloss holds up better to scrubbing," Harold’s voice said, appearing quietly beside her. "But the eggshell finish hides imperfections on the wall." She startled, then smiled, a genuine, easy expression that had become second nature to her. "It's for the bathroom," she said. "I was thinking of a pale green." He picked up a swatch, a colour called 'Sea Glass,' and held it under the fluorescent light, tilting it back and forth. "It’s a good choice. It won’t feel cold in the winter light." They stood there for several minutes, discussing the merits of different paint brands, their conversation as mundane and comfortably domestic as any other couple's in the store. Frank Henderson watched them from behind the counter, a bemused smile on his face. He'd never seen either of them look so at ease.

As they walked toward the checkout, Susan saw Widow Jensen by the pest control section, loudly interrogating a teenage employee about the most effective way to deal with squirrels. For a half-second, an image flashed in Susan’s mind: a darkened bedroom, the weight of a frail, sleeping foot in her hand, the smell of acetone. The memory was clear, but it had no power over her. It was like recalling a scene from a foreign film she had watched long ago. She felt a distant ache of pity for the woman she had been, the goblin driven by a pain so vast it had to be portioned out in tiny, violet drops. That person was a stranger to her now. The woman holding a can of 'Sea Glass' paint and a high-quality roller brush had a future she was building herself, one clean, steady coat at a time. The past was not erased, but it had been insulated, grounded, and tucked safely away where it could no longer cause a fire.

That evening, they sat on her porch as the last of the day's heat bled from the sky. The wicker table between them, once wobbly and unstable, was now solid, its legs reinforced with small, invisible metal brackets he had helped her install. She had painted it the same clean white as the porch railings. He was drinking a glass of her iced tea, and she was sketching in a small notebook—not a list of repairs, but a plan for a flower bed. The air was filled with the rhythmic, peaceful thrum of crickets and the occasional distant bark of a dog. "It's a good time of year to divide irises," he said, breaking the comfortable silence, his gaze fixed on the darkening edge of her yard. "You have to do it before the first frost if you want them to bloom next spring." She looked up from her sketch, her pencil poised over the page. "Is it difficult?" she asked. He shook his head. "Not if you have a sharp spade and know where to cut the rhizome." He paused, looking at her, a quiet offer hanging in the twilight air between them. "I could show you," he said. Susan smiled, a soft, steady expression that reached her eyes, clear and bright in the gathering dusk. "I'd like that," she said. Around them, the first fireflies of the evening began to appear, their gentle, rhythmic blinking a silent testament not to a broken system, but to the quiet, miraculous, and steady pulse of life.

The heart of it was the rhizome. Harold knelt in the soft, loamy soil of Susan’s new flowerbed, a trowel in one hand and a thick, knobby root in the other. It looked like a piece of ginger, pale and fibrous, with a fan of green leaves at one end and a tangle of white roots at the other. The late afternoon sun of early autumn cast long, gentle shadows across the yard, and the air was crisp with the clean, dry scent of impending change. Susan knelt beside him, her hands covered in dirt, watching with the focused attention of a dedicated apprentice. It had been weeks since his offer on the porch, and now, on this quiet Saturday, the lesson had commenced.

“It’s a storage organ,” he explained, his voice the familiar, practical rumble she had come to associate with a sense of underlying order. He pointed with the tip of his trowel to a series of faint rings on the rhizome’s surface. “Each one of these is a year’s growth. The old parts, back here, they’ve already bloomed. They won’t do it again. The energy is all moving forward, to the new growth.” He took a sharp, clean knife from his pocket and with a single, decisive movement, sliced through the rhizome, separating the younger, leafier section from the older, withered part. “You have to be ruthless. Get rid of the old wood. It just drains the plant.” He handed her the new section, its cut end white and moist. “Plant this. Not too deep. The top of the rhizome likes to feel the sun.”

Susan took the piece of plant, its unexpected weight a solid, living thing in her palm. She followed his instructions, digging a shallow hole and setting the rhizome in, carefully fanning the roots out before covering them with soil, leaving the top ridge exposed as he had directed. It was a simple act, but it felt profound, a kind of surgical hopefulness. They worked in comfortable silence for the next hour, a rhythmic team, digging, dividing, and replanting the overgrown clumps of irises he had brought from his own yard. Their conversation was sparse, a language of roots and soil and sun. It was a language she was beginning to understand, a language of how things grow, how they heal, and what they need to be left behind in order to flourish. The goblin had dealt in endings, in final adornments for a journey into the grey. This woman, with dirt under her fingernails and the sun on her back, was planting for the spring.

The news of Harold's accident reached her, as most significant news in Norman did, through the low-voltage current of town gossip. She was at Henderson’s Hardware two weeks later, buying a new blade for her pruning saw, when Frank Henderson leaned over the counter, his face a mask of solemn excitement. “You hear about Harold Belchamber? Took a tumble off a ladder over at the new dental clinic. They say he was lucky. Could’ve been his head, but he just broke his wrist. His left one, thank God, so he can still sign his invoices, but he’s out of commission for a while. A fella like that, his hands are his whole life. It’s a crying shame.” A cold dread, slick and oily and sickeningly familiar, washed over Susan for a moment. It wasn't the panic of her old life, but a sharp, clear ache of empathy. She imagined him, the man of absolute physical competence, suddenly rendered incapable. His frustration would be a palpable, dangerous thing. She paid for the saw blade, her hands moving on autopilot, thanked Frank for the information, and walked out of the store, a new, unwelcome kind of list forming in her mind.

She drove to his neat brick house, the same one where she had left the loaf of bread almost a year before. The plain white van was parked in the driveway, looking unnaturally still. She walked up the path and knocked on the front door, her heart a steady, determined drum. There was no answer. She knocked again, louder this time. She was about to turn away when she heard a muffled curse from inside, followed by the sound of a lock being clumsily fumbled with. The door opened to reveal Harold, his left arm encased in a heavy plaster cast and held in a sling, his face a thundercloud of pure, undiluted frustration. He was wearing a shirt that was buttoned wrong, and his hair, usually so neatly combed, was sticking up at an angle. He stared at her, not with anger, but with the caged fury of an animal whose limb is caught in a trap. “What?” he grunted, the single word a testament to his misery.

Susan did not flinch. She had stood on the other side of this dynamic, a mess of broken pieces being observed by his calm competence. She knew the language of despair, and she would not be cowed by it. “Frank Henderson told me,” she said, her voice even. “I brought you soup.” She held up a large glass jar filled with a thick lentil soup she had made the day before. He stared at the jar as if it were a complex and unsolvable puzzle. He couldn't take it. Not with one hand while trying to hold the door. The simple act of receiving a gift was a logistical impossibility. The frustration on his face deepened into something that looked dangerously close to shame. “I don’t need soup,” he muttered, his gaze fixed on the floor. “And I don’t need a nurse.” Susan met his defiance with a calm she hadn't known she possessed. “Good,” she replied, her voice softening slightly. “Because I’m not one. But it looks like you might need someone to open the jar.” She stepped past him, crossing the threshold into his quiet, ordered house, the jar of soup held in front of her like a passport.

His house was the antithesis of her own former chaos. It was a sanctuary of precision, where even the dust seemed afraid to settle without permission. Not a single stray piece of paper marred the surface of the entryway table; the floors were so clean they reflected the grey afternoon light like still water. It smelled of citrus cleaner and the faint, metallic scent of his workshop that clung to the air like a lingering ghost of his competence. This profound order made the sight of him, with his misaligned shirt and his aura of helpless rage, all the more jarring. He was a perfect machine with a snapped gear, grinding against his own casing. He followed her into the kitchen, his good hand clenched into a white-knuckled fist at his side, his silence a heavy, brooding presence.

The kitchen was a marvel of functional design. Stainless steel countertops were wiped to a gleaming finish, and every utensil hung from a magnetic strip on the wall in descending order of size. It was a room designed for efficiency, not for comfort. Susan walked directly to the counter, placed the jar of soup down with a solid thump, and began to methodically search for the cupboard with the saucepans. Harold stood in the doorway, a storm cloud contained by plaster and a cotton sling. “I can manage,” he bit out, the words sharp-edged and brittle. It was a lie born of a lifetime of self-reliance, a protest against the humiliating reality of his own body’s betrayal. Susan found a saucepan and placed it on the stove. She didn't look at him. “I know,” she said, her voice calm and even. The two words were a masterpiece of diplomacy. They did not challenge his statement; they simply acknowledged his will, while her actions addressed his need. It disarmed him, leaving him with nothing to fight against.

She twisted the lid on the jar of soup. It was on tight. She grunted with the effort, her own hands, once so weak and trembling, now strong and sure. The seal broke with a satisfying pop, and she poured the thick, fragrant soup into the saucepan, the smell of lentils and rosemary instantly domesticating the sterile room. While she waited for it to heat, she saw a can of dog food and a manual can opener on the counter, next to a full, untouched food bowl. She understood immediately. He had a dog. He had been trying, and failing, to perform the simplest of tasks: feeding his pet. This small, private failure was more intimate than any confession. He saw where her gaze had landed and his jaw tightened, a muscle jumping in his cheek. “The dog’s at the kennel,” he muttered, a clumsy, defensive lie. Susan turned from the stove and looked at him, her expression not one of pity, but of deep, quiet understanding. “Harold,” she said softly. “It’s alright.”

It was those three words, spoken with a simple, unadorned sincerity, that finally broke through his wall of rage. The fury did not vanish, but it collapsed inward, leaving a vast, hollow space of weary defeat in its place. He let out a long, shuddering breath, the sound of a man who had been holding it in for days, and sagged against the doorframe, the rigid anger draining out of him like sand from a sack. He looked old, and tired, and utterly human. He was no longer the competent, all-knowing electrician who had diagnosed her life; he was just a man with a broken arm who couldn’t open a can. Susan ladled the hot soup into a bowl, found a spoon, and placed it on the small kitchen table. He moved stiffly, like an old man, and sat down. He picked up the spoon with his right hand, the movement awkward and unfamiliar, and began to eat. They ate in silence, the only sounds the scrape of his spoon against the bowl and the hum of the refrigerator. The soup was thick and nourishing. After a few bites, he spoke, his voice low and gravelly, his eyes fixed on the bowl. “It’s good soup.” It was the closest he could come to an apology, an admission, a thank you.

When he was finished, Susan took the bowl and put it in the sink. She looked around the immaculate house and saw the small signs of his struggle. A pile of mail on the counter he couldn’t open. A half-tied shoelace on the one boot he’d managed to put on. A new, unopened bottle of aspirin with a childproof cap he would never be able to defeat. The chaos was creeping in at the edges of his ordered world. She knew she could not leave. This was not a debt to be repaid; it was a responsibility, an act of fellowship for the only other person on earth who understood the specific language of being broken. "I can sort through your mail," she offered, her tone practical, the same one he had used with her. "Make a pile for bills, a pile for junk." She picked up a letter opener from a tidy pen cup on the counter. "And I can open that aspirin for you before I go." He didn't answer. He just sat at his kitchen table, his shoulders slumped, his broken arm a heavy, useless weight in his lap. His silence was his consent, a quiet, grudging surrender to the unavoidable truth that for the first time in his life, Harold Belchamber needed help.

A routine, unspoken and immediate, began to form. Susan didn’t wait for his permission. She moved to the counter and began slitting open the envelopes with the letter opener, her movements efficient and devoid of hesitation. She sorted the mail into the three piles he had taught her, her own system mirrored back at him in his moment of need. He watched her, his one good hand resting on the table, the knuckles white. Every competent movement she made was a small, sharp indictment of his own uselessness. The quiet rustle of paper was the only sound for several minutes, a sound that grated on his nerves like sand in a bearing. He was a man of action, and all he could do was sit and be acted upon. It was a torment more profound than the dull, throbbing ache in his arm.

A low, mournful whine came from the back of the house, followed by the faint scratch of claws against a door. It was a sound of patient, hopeful complaint. Susan paused her sorting, her head tilting. "The kennel is very close by," she observed, her voice neutral, holding no accusation. The lie, so small and pathetic, lay exposed between them. Harold’s face darkened with a flush of shame. He had been so determined to project an image of stoic control, even in his lies, that he had forgotten the simple, undeniable needs of his own dog, a twelve-year-old border collie named Amp. He had managed to let him out into the backyard that morning but had been unable to coax him back in or manage the can of food. "His name is Amp," Harold said, the admission costing him more than he would ever let on. "He won’t come in for me."

Susan simply nodded, as if this were the most logical problem in the world. She went to the back door, slid it open, and made a soft, clicking sound with her tongue. A grey-muzzled collie with intelligent, worried eyes trotted in, looked at the cast on Harold’s arm, and gave a low, sympathetic whimper before nudging his good hand with a wet nose. Susan located the can of dog food, and with a few deft turns of the can opener, emptied its contents into the bowl. The sound of the dog eating, a series of happy, gobbling noises, filled the kitchen. It was the sound of a system restored to function, a problem solved by another’s hands. Harold watched the entire exchange, the humiliation warring with a grudging, infuriating sense of relief. When she was done, she moved to the living room, where his work boots sat. She knelt, and without a word, began to deftly tie the laces on the one he had managed to put on, her fingers moving with a sureness that was both a comfort and a curse. Kneeling at his feet, she was a mirror image of the goblin he had once hunted, but now the act was one of practical, grounded care, a reversal of roles so complete it left him speechless.

She did not leave. When the mail was sorted and the dog was fed, she looked at the clock on the wall. It was nearly five. "I have a shift at the library tomorrow at ten," she stated, not as an apology or an excuse, but as a simple fact that would structure their immediate future. "I can come by at eight to help with breakfast. And I can stop on my way home in the evening." It was not a question. It was a plan, a schedule, a new circuit diagram laid out to bypass the broken component that was his left arm. He wanted to refuse, to rage against the dying of his own competence, to tell her he could manage. But he knew he couldn’t. He couldn’t button his shirt properly, he couldn’t make a pot of coffee, he couldn’t safely drive his van. He was grounded, and he knew it. All he could do was give a single, stiff nod of assent.

The next few days unfolded in a routine of forced, excruciating intimacy. Susan arrived in the mornings, bringing with her the scent of the crisp autumn air and a quiet capability that both soothed and infuriated him. She made coffee, she buttered his toast, she buttoned the cuffs of his shirts. She learned the hyper-organized landscape of his house, where the tea was kept in a canister labeled ‘TEA’, and his vitamins were arranged by day in a pill organizer. In the evenings, she would return, bringing groceries or a simple, home-cooked meal that was infinitely better than the frozen dinners he would have otherwise been forced to microwave. She would listen as he gave her clipped, frustrated instructions on how to perform simple tasks he could no longer manage, like replacing a burned-out bulb in his workshop or tightening a loose handle on a cabinet. She became his hands, an extension of his will, and for a man used to being a self-contained unit, the dependency was a constant, low-grade fever of irritation.

One afternoon, a call came from the Norman Geriatric Clinic. The lights in the main waiting room were flickering, and Henderson, the facility manager, was in a panic. Harold’s immediate, ingrained instinct was to grab his tools and go. The frustration of being unable to do so was a physical blow. He sat listening to Henderson's frantic description, his mind automatically diagnosing the problem—almost certainly a failing ballast in one of the old fluorescent fixtures—and his inability to act was a fresh wave of torment. He hung up the phone with a sharp click, his face set in a grim mask. Susan, who had been quietly reading a book in the armchair, looked over at him. "The clinic?" she asked. He just grunted in response. She knew that building, knew its sounds and its systems in a way no one else did. She set her book down. "Tell me what to do," she said.

His refusal was instantaneous and absolute, a reflex born of a lifetime of sole proprietorship over his craft. “No,” he snapped, the single word as sharp as a clipped wire. He pushed himself straighter in his chair, wincing as the movement pulled at his broken arm. “It’s not a lamp cord, Susan. It’s a commercial fixture. Two-hundred-and-seventy-seven volts. You don’t know what you’re looking at. You could get killed. You could start a fire. You could make it ten times worse.” He was painting a rapid-fire collage of disaster, each scenario more dire than the last. It was the frantic protest of a master craftsman forced to watch an amateur approach his life’s work with a hammer. It was his professional pride, his ingrained sense of responsibility, and the terrifying, galling reality of his own helplessness all rolled into one jagged, angry rebuttal.

Susan did not argue. She did not try to reassure him or defend her capabilities. She simply stood there, a quiet island in the storm of his frustration, and let his words wash over her. When he finally ran out of breath, his face flushed with the effort, she just looked at the phone, then back at him. “Henderson is panicking,” she said, her voice calm and factual. “The lights are flickering in a building full of elderly people’s records. It’s almost night. No one else is coming, Harold. You know that. And you can’t leave it like that. It’s a fault in the system.” She used his own language, his own logic, turning it back on him like a mirror. She wasn’t claiming to be an electrician. She was offering to be his avatar, a remote-controlled tool. “I can follow instructions. You know I can.”

The truth of her words was undeniable, and it was that very logic that infuriated him. He was trapped by his own principles. The need to fix what was broken was a compulsion stronger than his pride. The thought of that flickering ballast, an unstable current surging through the clinic’s wiring all night, was a torment that outweighed the humiliation of sending her in his place. He wrestled with it for a long, silent moment, his jaw working, the muscles in his neck corded with tension. Finally, with a sound that was half-groan, half-surrender, he slammed his good hand down on the arm of his chair. “Fine,” he spat, the word tasting like poison. “Fine. But you do exactly what I say. Exactly. You don’t touch anything until I tell you to. You question nothing. Get the keys to the van. They’re on the hook by the door. We’re going to the workshop first.”

The workshop was Harold’s mind made manifest, and entering it without him felt like a profound trespass. The scent of oil and solder and cool metal was the very essence of him. Tools hung on the pegboard, each one casting a shadow on the perfect, hand-traced outline behind it. It was a space of absolute, uncompromising order. With the phone pressed to her ear, she became his remote hands, his voice a disembodied presence guiding her through his own inner sanctum. “Red toolbox on the main bench. Top drawer. There’s a multimeter. Black, with a yellow rubber casing. Got it? Okay. Now, the side compartment. You need a wire stripper with a blue handle. Not the red one, the blue one is for thicker gauge. And a nut driver set. The one in the green case.” He was barking commands, his anxiety transmitting clearly across the line, but Susan moved with a calm, focused grace. She gathered the tools, feeling their solid, purposeful weight in her hands. She was not just borrowing his equipment; she was being entrusted with the very instruments of his identity.

Driving his van was the strangest, most transformative act of all. The driver’s seat was molded to his larger frame, the steering wheel thick and worn smooth in the places where his hands always rested. From this new vantage point, the world looked different. The van, which had once felt like a predator’s vehicle in her memory, was now simply a machine, a tool chest on wheels, and she was in control. It was filled with the familiar smells of his workshop and a faint, lingering scent of the coffee he always drank in the mornings. As she pulled out of his driveway and headed toward the Geriatric Clinic, she felt a profound and dizzying shift in the tectonic plates of her own history. The goblin who had once crept toward this building in the dark, armed with nail polish and grief, was now driving toward it in broad daylight, armed with a multimeter and a purpose that was not her own, but one she had chosen to shoulder.

Henderson, the facility manager, met her at the main entrance, his face a mask of anxious relief that curdled into open bewilderment when he saw it was her. He stared, his mouth slightly agape, taking in the familiar face of the former cleaning woman now holding a heavy-duty toolbox. “Susan? What… Harold sent you?” The skepticism in his voice was thick enough to cut with a knife. Susan looked him directly in the eye, her expression unreadable. “There was an accident. He broke his wrist,” she stated simply, offering no further apology or explanation. She held up her phone, where she had initiated a video call. Harold’s grim, disembodied face stared out from the screen. “She’s with me, Henderson,” Harold’s voice crackled from the small speaker. “She’s my hands. Now get out of her way and let her work.” The sheer, unshakeable authority in his voice vaporized the manager’s doubt. He simply nodded, dumbstruck, and stepped aside.

The waiting room was just as she remembered it, but viewed from a new and alien perspective. The linoleum floors she had mopped hundreds of times now felt like a stage. Above her, the long fluorescent fixture flickered and buzzed, a sick, rhythmic strobing that cast the room in a nauseating, erratic light. It was the heartbeat of the building’s illness, a problem she was now here to solve. She wheeled a tall rolling ladder from the utility closet and positioned it beneath the faulty light. With the phone tucked into her breast pocket, an earbud feeding Harold’s voice directly into her head, she ascended. It was like having a ghost on her shoulder, a demanding, omniscient, and deeply anxious ghost. “Okay, pop the ceiling tile to the left of the fixture first. You need to see the junction box.” His voice was a low, constant murmur, a stream of pure, technical instruction. “That’s where the main power comes in. Now, take out the multimeter. Set it to AC voltage. Touch the probes to the black and the white wires. Tell me what you see.”

She followed his instructions to the letter, her fear a cold, tight knot in her stomach, but her hands steady. She reported the voltage reading. She killed the correct breaker, plunging the room into near darkness, lit only by the emergency exit signs. Guided by his voice, she opened the fixture, located the ballast—a heavy, brick-like component—and began the methodical process of disconnecting it. “There are four blue wires, two red, a black, and a white. Disconnect the black and white first.” He was a master puppeteer, and she was the marionette, her fingers his, her eyes his. It was an act of supreme, terrifying trust on both their parts. She snipped the old wires, stripped the new ones, and connected the new ballast he had instructed her to grab from his van, her fingers twisting the wire nuts until they were tight and secure. “Okay,” his voice said, a tense calm in her ear. “That’s it. Put the cover back on. Go flip the breaker.” She descended the ladder, her legs shaking slightly, walked to the utility closet, and pushed the breaker switch up. For a second, there was nothing. Then, with a barely audible hum, the light flickered once and blazed to life—steady, silent, and overwhelmingly bright. On the other end of the phone, there was a long, drawn-out silence, and then the sound of a deep, shuddering exhalation, a sound of relief so profound it was almost a prayer.

The silence in the waiting room was absolute, a profound quiet that felt more significant than the buzzing it had replaced. The light from the newly repaired fixture was clean, white, and unforgiving, illuminating the scuffed linoleum and the faded upholstery of the chairs with a stark, unwavering clarity. Henderson, the facility manager, stared up at the light, his mouth still slightly agape, as if he had just witnessed an act of impossible magic. He turned his bewildered gaze to Susan, who was methodically packing the tools back into the red toolbox. She was no longer the former cleaning woman. In his eyes, she had undergone a strange and inexplicable alchemy, transformed into something else entirely. She closed the lid of the toolbox, the snap of the latches a sound of decisive finality. "It was a faulty ballast," she said, her voice calm and steady, repeating the diagnosis Harold had given her. The technical term sounded natural on her tongue, a piece of a new language she had learned. Without waiting for a reply, she picked up the toolbox, descended the ladder, and walked out of the clinic, leaving the manager standing alone in the steady, brilliant light.

Driving Harold’s van back through the quiet, darkened streets of Norman was a fundamentally different experience than the journey out. The adrenaline that had sharpened her focus was now ebbing away, leaving in its place a deep, thrumming sense of accomplishment that was both exhilarating and terrifying. She had stepped into the heart of a system, a place of invisible power and tangible danger, and under duress, she had repaired it. The steering wheel felt solid and real beneath her hands, a conduit to the machine she commanded. She thought of the goblin, the creature of the night she had once been, creeping through shadows, her only tools a file and a bottle of cheap polish. That creature had sought to leave a mark, a secret splash of colour. This woman, the one driving a tradesman's van with a box of professional tools on the passenger seat, had brought back the light. The power she felt was not the frantic, compulsive energy of her grief, but the clean, steady current of pure capability.

He was waiting for her in his living room, sitting in the armchair under the light of a single lamp, the rest of the house dark. He hadn't moved, but the tension in the room was palpable, a low-grade hum of anxiety. He had been blind and helpless, a commander sending his only soldier into battle, and the waiting had been a unique and exquisite form of torture. When she walked in, placing the toolbox on the floor with a heavy, satisfying thud, he didn't ask if she had succeeded. He could see it in the way she carried herself, in the absence of panic in her eyes. "Henderson called," he said, his voice a low grumble. "He sounded like he'd seen a ghost." He looked at her, truly looked at her, and for the first time, his gaze held not just concern or grudging acceptance, but a deep, clear, and undeniable respect. He was seeing her not as a patient, not as a project, but as a peer. "You did good," he said, the two words delivered with the same factual gravity as a voltage reading. It was the highest praise he was capable of giving, and it landed in the quiet room with the weight of a sacrament.

The incident at the clinic altered the very nature of their arrangement. The dynamic shifted from one of caretaker and patient to a strange, unspoken partnership. The morning after the repair, when she arrived to make coffee, she found the Belchamber Electrical phone, a rugged-looking cell phone distinct from his personal one, sitting on the kitchen table next to a newly started legal pad. “It won’t stop ringing,” he said, his voice thick with frustration. “People hear the power is back on and they think I can just magically appear. I need you to answer it. Tell them I’m out of commission for six weeks. Emergencies only. Take a message. Start a list.” He was, in essence, deputizing her. She was no longer just his hands; she was now his voice, his scheduler, his public face. The job expanded beyond domestic aid into the core of his professional life. She spent her mornings on the phone, her voice a calm and steady counterpoint to the panicked homeowners and fretful business owners on the other end. She learned to triage their problems, to distinguish between a genuine fire risk and a simple tripped breaker. She ordered parts online, navigated the labyrinthine websites of electrical suppliers, and brought a quiet, methodical order to the chaotic pile of invoices and receipts that represented the business side of his life, a system he had always neglected in favor of the more satisfying, tangible work of his hands.

Her afternoons were often spent in the workshop, which had become a kind of classroom. He would sit on a stool, his arm in its sling, and direct her in tasks that required two hands. She learned to use a bench grinder to sharpen drill bits, the shower of sparks initially terrifying, then beautiful. He taught her how to braid wires for a custom extension cord, how to test a motor’s continuity with the multimeter, how to organize a chaotic drawer of wire nuts by color and size. She was a quick and careful study, her hands retaining the muscle memory of each new task. He was a demanding, impatient, and brilliant teacher. He never praised her directly, but she could sense his approval in the decreasing frequency of his corrections, in the longer silences as he simply watched her work. She was building a new skill set, a new identity, one component at a time, right there on his workbench. One afternoon, while she was methodically soldering a connection on a circuit board for an antique radio he was restoring as a hobby, he said, almost to himself, “You have steady hands.” The observation was delivered in the same tone he might use to comment on the tensile strength of a wire, but coming from him, it felt like a benediction.

The town of Norman, with its finely tuned network of observation and speculation, did not fail to notice the change. Frank Henderson’s account of the events at the clinic, embellished with each retelling, became the stuff of local legend. The story spread that Harold Belchamber, the town’s resident mechanical genius, had taken on an apprentice, and more shockingly, that the apprentice was Susan Blackwood, the quiet, reclusive woman who used to clean the clinic. She was seen driving his van, walking into Henderson’s with a list of parts written in Harold’s blocky handwriting, her demeanor shifting from timid to purposeful. The town’s gossip, which had once painted her as a tragic figure and then as the victim of a bizarre nocturnal prankster, now recast her in a new, more formidable role. She was no longer just "poor Susan." She was "Harold's apprentice," a title that conferred a strange and powerful new identity. Susan was aware of the whispers, the curious glances, but they no longer felt like judgments. They were simply data points, confirming her own internal transformation. She had a purpose that was visible to the world, and the confidence it gave her was a shield against the town’s relentless curiosity.

The day the cast was scheduled to come off arrived with a sense of quiet, looming significance. The six weeks were up. The broken bone, the catalyst for their strange and transformative partnership, was healed. Susan drove him to the orthopedic clinic in the next town, the silence in the van thick with unspoken questions. What would happen now? The practical, urgent need for her presence in his life was about to be erased. She waited in the stark, sterile waiting room, the minutes stretching into an eternity. When he finally emerged from the examination room, his arm was free, pale and thin and fragile-looking, but whole. He flexed his fingers slowly, a look of profound, primal satisfaction on his face. The electrician was reconnected. The master of the machine was back online. He was whole again, and by extension, he was self-sufficient. The drive home was even quieter than the drive there. She could feel the end of her tenure approaching, the return to her own quiet life, a life that now felt both fuller and, in the face of this impending change, strangely empty.

She walked him to the door of his house, the keys to his van feeling heavy and foreign in her hand. This was it. The handover. The end of her role. "Well," she said, her voice sounding unnaturally bright, "I guess you won't be needing me to answer your phone anymore." She held out the keys. He looked at them, then at her face. The grim mask of frustration he had worn for weeks was gone, replaced by an expression she couldn't quite read. It was a look of deep, analytical thought, as if he were diagnosing the final, most complex circuit of all. He did not take the keys. "I spent last night going over the books," he said, his voice quiet, matter-of-fact. "The business side. The part you've been handling." He paused, organizing his thoughts. "Since you started answering the phone, scheduling the jobs, and handling the invoicing, my projected net income is up by twenty-two percent. My parts overhead is down by nine percent because you order what I need, not what I think I might need. The system is more efficient." He was presenting it like a technical report, a summary of data. He was showing his work. "I have a backlog of non-emergency jobs that will take me three months to clear. The phone is still ringing. The paperwork is still a disaster waiting to happen." He finally looked her directly in the eye. "I thought I just needed my hand back. I was wrong. I need a partner." The word hung in the air between them, charged with a voltage that had nothing to do with electricity. He still hadn't taken the keys. "The job is yours. If you want it."
